title: Google's Grown-Up Phase Won't Be Boring
summary: Search giant's stellar profit and best year of growth since 2007 set up a tough act to follow. Adulthood is a good look for Google, but that doesn't mean its life will get much easier.

title: Biden's Southern Border Crisis Isn't Going Away
summary: The administration lets a crisis fester, and the Democratic Party will pay a political price.. When is Joe Biden going to realize that Donald Trump didn't lose the election in 2020 because of his stance on illegal immigration? The Biden administration doesn't seem much interested in the havoc on our southern border, but the problem isn't going away. If anything, the situation has been worsening, and Republicans are certain to tee up border security as a midterm campaign theme.

title: Roll Over, Kierkegaard, It's All 'Existential'
summary: For threats, risks, crises, even movies-one adjective pops up.. A Boston Globe columnist wrote last summer, "Philosophers have struggled for millennia to answer the existential question: Why did the chicken cross the road?" Here's my question: Why are writers and politicians today trying so hard to shoehorn the word existential into sentences?

title: 'Powers and Thrones' Review: Plagues, Princes and Pardons
summary: Why did Rome fall and the long cycle of invasions in Europe begin? The answer may be locked in the rings of a tree in Tibet.. 'What has been done is what will be done, and there is nothing new under the sun." Dan Jones places this canard from Ecclesiastes as the epigraph for his often surprising "Powers and Thrones: A New History of the Middle Ages." After such an opening salvo, how can he offer a "new" history? In fact, Mr. Jones does just that, recalibrating our sense of what the old and the now have in common. Using continuous references to the present, enabling modern readers to understand not only the "whats" but the "whys" behind events in the distant past, "Powers and Thrones" makes those events immediate, personal and understandable. Much like Jared Diamond in "Guns, Germs, and Steel," Mr. Jones recontextualizes medieval history by using recent findings about the impact of climate, technology and pathogens on human cultures. His narrative stretches across a wide area of interconnected empires, cultures, and wars: from China to Africa; from the steppes of the Mongols to the deserts of Arabia.

title: GM Earnings Rose Sharply in 2021
summary: Auto maker says it needs to accelerate its electric-vehicle efforts. General Motors Co. said it plans to accelerate the timetable for some electric-vehicle launches and will establish a third factory to build plug-in trucks, anticipating a sharp rise in demand for EVs.

title: Are Colleges Discriminating Against Asian Applicants?
summary: University admission policies consistently give preference to other minorities.. Editor's note: In this Future View, students discuss colleges discriminating against Asians. Next week we'll ask, "Are Neil Young, Joni Mitchell and other artists right to pull their music from Spotify until it drops or censors the Joe Rogan podcast?" Students should click here to submit opinions of fewer than 250 words before Feb. 8. The best responses will be published that night.

title: New York's Democratic Jerrymander
summary: Democrats draw a map that gives them an edge in 85% of House seats.. Gerrymandering is an old enough practice that it was named for a Founding Father, Elbridge Gerry, but henceforth in New York it should be spelled jerrymander. See nearby the district that Democrats in Albany have staked out for Democratic Rep. Jerry Nadler. Your first instinct might be to grab the cartographer and do a field sobriety test.

title: Xi Jinping's Year of the Tiger
summary: The stage-managed Olympics can't conceal economic worries.. This should be a banner week for Chinese President Xi Jinping. His country is celebrating the lunar new year, the most important holiday in the Chinese calendar, and the Beijing Winter Olympics open Friday. If Mr. Xi isn't enjoying the festivities, that may be due to fresh signs the economy is in trouble-which is largely his fault.

title: Putin Says West Failed to Address His Demands in Ukraine Standoff
summary: Russian leader expresses willingness to continue talks; Ukraine President Zelensky meets with U.K., Polish prime ministers. KYIV, Ukraine-President Vladimir Putin of Russia said the U.S. and its European allies had "basically ignored" Moscow's demands for security assurances but expressed a willingness to continue talks as Russian troops maneuvered near Ukraine's borders and Kyiv rushed to bolster its defenses.

title: Why Xavier Becerra Can't Be Fired
summary: The HHS secretary is out of his depth, but everyone knew that when he was appointed.. The White House is apparently experiencing buyer's remorse over its appointment of Xavier Becerra to run the Health and Human Services Department. This is the cost of indulging identity politics in a pandemic.

title: Winter Storm to Disrupt Central U.S. With Snow, Sleet and Ice
summary: Illinois, Ohio and Michigan will bear the brunt of it, National Weather Service Says. A storm heading for the central U.S. threatens to bring heavy snow, sleet and freezing rain to a wide swath of the country this week.

title: Truckers and Canada's Conservatives
summary: Opposition leader Erin O'Toole has earned a leadership challenge.. Thousands of truckers and their supporters drove to Canada's capital over the weekend, demanding an end to vaccine mandates and the reign of Liberal Prime Minister Justin Trudeau. They may leave Ottawa with a different scalp: that of Conservative leader Erin O'Toole.

title: Spotify and Rogan Are the Real Adults
summary: The company meets aging rockers Neil Young and Joni Mitchell halfway, but it's not good enough for them.. Neil Young found a way to remind you he exists. So did Joni Mitchell. These children of the '60s may not recall the spirit of the Berkeley free speech movement, but they do the era's sanctimony, with their ultimatum to Spotify to stop streaming their music if it continues to host the antic, disobedient podcast of comedian and actor Joe Rogan.

title: Google Parent Caps Blockbuster Year With Sales Gains
summary: Search giant plans a 20-for-1 stock split; its profit rose by a third. Google parent Alphabet Inc. posted another quarter of strong sales growth, capping a year when profit nearly doubled despite mounting regulatory pressure that threatens the search giant's future.

title: If America Doesn't Set the Digital Trade Agenda, China Will
summary: A chance for Biden to defy protectionists on the left, rally allies, create jobs and promote economic growth.. Despite his talk about "extreme competition" with China, President Biden is abandoning the fight over who will set the ground rules for the future digital economy. U.S. trade policy remains stuck in the past because Democrats fear the wrath of progressive protectionists and Republicans fear a backlash from reactionary economic isolationists. Yet the public's outlook differs. The Chicago Council on Global Affairs reports that mainstream America thinks trade is good for the U.S. economy (75%) and that globalization is mainly good (68%).

title: New Orleans Begins Covid-19 Vaccine Mandate for All Students
summary: School districts elsewhere, including in Los Angeles, San Diego and Washington, D.C., are also seeking to add requirements for coronavirus vaccines. New Orleans on Tuesday launched a Covid-19 vaccine mandate in public schools for students five years of age and older, making it the first major U.S. city to require coronavirus shots in schools.

title: Exxon, Chevron Hit Gushers of Cash
summary: Large Western oil companies are posting their most profitable years since the pandemic as oil prices rise, attracting investors who had fled. The world's big Western oil companies are back in the money and once again attracting strong interest from investors as crude prices rise to their highest levels in years.

title: AT&T Sets WarnerMedia Spinoff Plan and Lowers Its Dividend
summary: Shareholders will get 0.24 shares in new media company and reduced annual dividend of $1.11 a share. AT&T Inc. said it would roughly halve its dividend payout and divest itself of its WarnerMedia division through a spinoff that would give shareholders 0.24 share for each AT&T share they own, a move that would complete its retreat from the entertainment business.

title: Biden Seeks Calmer Supreme Court Confirmation Process in Outreach to GOP
summary: President says he is serious about Constitution's 'advise and consent' as he meets with top senators.

title: Gilead's Revenue Declines on Waning Sales of Covid-19 Drug
summary: Decrease in revenue for remdesivir comes amid falling pandemic hospitalizations. Gilead Sciences Inc.'s revenue fell in the fourth quarter, as sales of its Covid-19 treatment remdesivir waned amid greater vaccine availability and declining hospitalization numbers.

title: Trump's Comments Fuel Bipartisan Effort to Clarify Role of Vice President in Elections
summary: Sen. Susan Collins of Maine leads effort to change Electoral Count Act. WASHINGTON-A bipartisan effort to clarify the vice president's role in certifying election results is gaining momentum and potentially expanding to include other areas of voting law, fueled by recent comments from former President Donald Trump that his former vice president should have overturned the result of the 2020 election.

title: Long Covid: What to Know About Lingering Symptoms of a Covid-19 Infection
summary: What the latest research, as well as doctors and patients, say about the condition. Some people who have had Covid-19 are still experiencing lingering symptoms weeks, months or as much as a year after infection, even if the illness was a mild case. Scientists, physicians and patients have dubbed the condition long Covid.

title: Comcast, Goldman Sachs Resume PAC Giving to Republican Election Objectors
summary: The companies joined others that are giving again to lawmakers who voted against certifying President Biden's election win after Jan. 6 Capitol riot by Trump supporters. WASHINGTON-Political action committees for Comcast Corp. and Goldman Sachs Group Inc. have resumed giving money to one or more of the 147 Republican lawmakers who voted to object to the certification of President Biden's election after the Jan. 6 Capitol riot by supporters of former GOP President Donald Trump, new filings show.

title: U.S. Stocks Finish Higher After Choppy Trading Session
summary: Investors weigh earnings reports, fresh economic data. U.S. stocks advanced Tuesday after a late-afternoon rally helped indexes notch a three-day winning streak.

title: Historically Black Colleges Targeted by Bomb Threats
summary: Classes were disrupted or canceled on more than a dozen campuses; no bombs found so far. At least 16 historically Black colleges and universities in the U.S. said they received bomb threats Tuesday, disrupting classes or causing them to be canceled.

title: Brian Flores Sues NFL Alleging Discrimination Against Black Coaches
summary: The recently fired Dolphins coach alleges racism in the hiring and retention of Black coaches. Brian Flores, the recently fired coach of the Miami Dolphins, has filed a lawsuit against the National Football League and three specific teams, alleging that Black coaches such as himself are discriminated against in pursuing coaching opportunities.

title: Job Openings, Quits Remained Elevated at End of Last Year
summary: Private-sector data for January showed early signs of a pullback in demand for workers. The U.S. labor market remained tight at the end of last year with job openings and worker turnover hovering near the highest levels on record, though there are signs demand cooled as the Omicron variant disrupted the economy in January.

title: FedEx Restores Some Freight Services Suspended by Staff Shortages
summary: Delivery giant says Omicron coronavirus surge has caused temporary shortages of crew and staff in its Express network. FedEx Corp. said it had restored some of its airfreight services that had been suspended last month due to staffing shortages caused by the Omicron variant.

title: Car Fatalities Rose in 2021 at Fastest Clip in Nearly Half a Century
summary: There were over 30,000 car-crash deaths in the U.S. in the first nine months of 2021, new projections show. There were over 30,000 car-crash deaths in the U.S. in the first nine months of 2021, a 12% surge that marks the largest increase in fatalities since reporting began nearly half a century ago, according to projections released Tuesday by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

title: UPS Raises Dividend as Profit, Revenue Surge
summary: Delivery company ships fewer packages than a year ago but is generating more money per piece. United Parcel Service Inc. is making more money shipping fewer packages and rewarding investors with a meatier dividend payout.

title: Bond Market Hints at Calm After Disruptive Selloff
summary: Yield on 10-year Treasury has been hovering around 1.8% after nearly reaching 1.9% in mid-January. Yields on longer-term U.S. government bonds have shown signs of stabilizing in recent days, easing the pressure generated on stocks by their rapid early-year climb.

title: Lockheed Martin Poaches CFO From Rival L3Harris
summary: The defense giant's appointment of Jesus "Jay" Malave comes six months after Ken Possenriede unexpectedly retired. Defense giant Lockheed Martin Corp. recruited a new finance chief from smaller rival L3Harris Technologies Inc., a rare transfer between two of the U.S.'s prime defense contractors.

title: SeaWorld Looks to Buy Fellow Theme Park Operator Cedar Fair
summary: Cedar Fair said it has received an unsolicited nonbinding proposal from SeaWorld Entertainment. Cedar Fair LP said SeaWorld Entertainment Inc. has proposed a deal that would combine two theme park operators as the entertainment industry plots its future amid Covid-19 uncertainty.

title: AMC Stock Jumps on Revenue Guidance for Holiday Quarter
summary: Movie-theater chain posted preliminary fourth-quarter results that showed revenue topping analyst expectations. Shares of AMC Entertainment Holdings Inc. jumped as much as 13% in premarket trading after the company posted preliminary fourth-quarter results that showed revenue topping analyst expectations.

title: 'Pam & Tommy' Review: A Grown-Up Tale of Adult Entertainment
summary: The Hulu series about the notorious '90s Pamela Anderson and Tommy Lee video offers more than just lewd celebrity schadenfreude.. As moms always used to say, never leave the house without wearing clean underwear. ("What if you got in an accident?") Today's savvier mothers will include, "Don't put anything in a text that you wouldn't want on a billboard." And those who followed the saga of Pamela Anderson and Tommy Lee circa 1997 might add, "Don't have sex on camera if you don't want it on the internet."

title: 'Multitudes' Review: The American Folk Art Museum at 60
summary: The institution celebrates its anniversary with an exhibition of some 400 objects from its collection.. New York

title: Fire at North Carolina Fertilizer Plant Forces Thousands to Evacuate
summary: Officials warn the ammonium nitrate at Winston-Salem plant could explode; Wake Forest University cancels classes. A fire at a fertilizer facility in Winston-Salem, N.C., forced thousands of residents to evacuate their homes amid concerns over chemicals in the plant that could lead to an explosion.

title: Rihanna Is Expecting a Real Gem
summary: Under layers of gemstones and vintage fashion, the singer offered a highly accessorized take on the now-ubiquitous maternity shoot.. Pop superstar Rihanna and rapper A$AP Rocky's baby will be entertainment-industry royalty.

title: What to Know About Omicron and Its Symptoms
summary: Fast-moving strain continues to spread globally but might still be susceptible to current vaccines. Since it was discovered in South Africa in late November, the Omicron variant has spread quickly, infecting millions of people around the world.

title: Israel's Military to Remove Two Officers Over Death of Elderly Palestinian-American
summary: IDF, following U.S.-supported investigation, says death was result of moral failure by soldiers. RAMALLAH, West Bank-Israel's military said two of its officers would be removed from their posts over the death last month of an elderly Palestinian-American man who suffered a heart attack after he was bound, gagged and eventually abandoned in a courtyard.

title: Jumping Jacks (Wednesday Crossword, February 2)
Internal Probe Finds No Wrongdoing at Pennsylvania Pension System
summary: Investigators from Womble Bond Dickinson blame investment consultant Aon for misreporting returns for the Pennsylvania Public School Employees' Retirement System. An internal investigation has cleared the investment staff and now-retired senior executives of Pennsylvania's largest pension of wrongdoing in miscalculating investment results near the end of 2020, an error that unleashed months of turmoil at the Pennsylvania Public School Employees' Retirement System.

title: This Chicken Meatballs Recipe Makes Smart Use of Salsa Verde
summary: The tomatillo salsa is not only the sauce for this dish; it's also what the tender meatballs simmer in, picking up piquant flavor in the process.. IN THE MANY kitchens where chef Cristina Martinez has cooked over the course of her career, in her current home of Philadelphia as well as her native Mexico, she has drawn on the fundamentals she gleaned cooking alongside her mother from the time she was a small child. She mastered these chicken meatballs in salsa verde, her third Slow Food Fast recipe, at the age of 6, and it remains a go-to today.

title: Payments for Order Flow Surged in 2021
summary: Earnings from selling their customers' order flow to electronic trading firms rose 33% last year. Brokerages serving individual investors received a windfall last year for selling their customers' order flow to electronic trading firms, even as the practice faced increasing scrutiny from regulators.

title: Bad Weather, Supply-Chain Woes Push Up Coffee Prices
summary: Arabica coffee futures rose 76% in 2021 and have continued to advance. Higher prices are here for your morning cup of joe.

title: Exxon's Cash Means Harder Decisions Ahead
summary: Company's strong results highlight tensions that could arise as its board contemplates how to allocate its cash in the future. A bruising pandemic and an activist-led board makeover later, Exxon Mobil Corp. is back. Well, almost.

title: U.S. Covid-19 Hospitalizations Extend Their Fall While Deaths Keep Rising
summary: CDC study adds to evidence that people who are vaccinated and boosted fare better during Omicron wave than the unvaccinated. The number of hospital patients with Covid-19 continues to fall in the U.S., adding to signs that the Omicron wave of the pandemic is ebbing, even though deaths from the virus are on the rise.

title: India Arie, Graham Nash to Leave Spotify, Following Neil Young's Protest of Joe Rogan
summary: Announcements are latest in a string of moves made by other musicians in recent days. Singer-songwriters Graham Nash and India Arie said they plan to pull their music from Spotify Technology SA , following Neil Young in objection to the platform's star podcaster Joe Rogan.

title: Fed Nominee Has Studied How Policies Affect Economic Opportunities
summary: Lisa Cook is likely to consider the impact of rate increases across demographic segments and different parts of economy, associates say. Economist Lisa Cook has often focused her research on policies that promote broad economic opportunity, particularly for racial minorities and women, an approach she could soon bring to the central bank and its policy making.

title: Answering Biden: Here Is What Republicans Are For
summary: In the way that Democrats emphasize 'caring,' the GOP's message needs to touch people's most visceral hopes.. Joseph Epstein is right that the Republican Party needs a message ("What Are Republicans For?" op-ed, Jan. 26). But "to map out the true domain of government," as Mr. Epstein quotes Roger Scruton, is a hard sell in attention-starved times. In the way that Democrats emphasize "caring," the message needs to touch people's most visceral hopes.

title: For Markets, the January Selloff Marks the End of the Pandemic
summary: Stock valuations and the 10-year Treasury yield are both back to where they were before the Covid-19 crisis. To look at stock valuations, the pandemic might never have happened.

title: Moving On to the Next Stage of the Pandemic
summary: The federal government can 'raise the cost' of opting to not be vaccinated.. Despite overwhelming evidence of the benefits of vaccination, some 37% of Americans haven't been fully vaccinated ("Protesters March Against Vaccine Mandates," U.S. News, Jan. 24). The government should stop trying to reason with the vaccine-mandate deniers. Instead, it should set a price for their noncompliance. Life and health insurance is more expensive for people who smoke, partly to get people to modify their behavior and to ensure other policyholders don't subsidize their bad life choices. The government should act in the same manner.

title: Cryptocurrencies, Criminality and the State
summary: The speed at which crypto moves and the anonymity accorded the transactions is a gift to the criminal and terrorist world.. In "Cryptocurrency Doesn't Amount to Much" (op-ed, Jan. 25), Steve Hanke and Matt Sekerke neglect a compelling reason for governments to refrain from monetizing cryptocurrencies. A major purpose of these cryptocurrencies is to get governments out of the business of creating money or, at a minimum, provide people an alternative to government money. Calls for government involvement in making cryptocurrencies stable and mainstream can be a gauge of how well the cryptocurrencies have been achieving that goal.

title: The Met Misses the Big Picture
summary: A plaque at the Metropolitan Museum of Art reveals a serious shortcoming in intersectionality.. Eleanor James's distressing letter about the Metropolitan Museum of Art (Jan. 26) reveals a shortcoming in intersectionality. The museum's plaques fault Madame Lavoisier on the colonial provenance of her muslin dress, but ignore her as a married woman. She is painted with her husband, Antoine, in his laboratory because she was his research partner. She translated scientific papers, keeping him au fait with advances abroad. After his execution in 1794, she compiled and published his papers, preserving his work in chemistry. This was not just another beautifully dressed French lady.

title: What Is There to Say About Our Politicians?
summary: 'Give 'em the hook,' of course.. As a young man in Chicago, my grandfather adored vaudeville ("Jackie Gleason's Insurance in a Trunk" by Bob Greene, op-ed, Jan. 19), from which he borrowed the audience cry that he would use for the rest of his life to dismiss inferior products: "Give 'em the hook." When an act wasn't up to snuff, that cry brought from the wings a long staff with a hook, like a shepherd's crook, on the end. The crook fastened around the unfortunate act to drag it off the stage.

title: Mardi Gras in the Covid Era: The Smarter Way to Join This Year's Festivities
summary: Carnival season is gearing up in New Orleans but with new rules in place. Here's how to join the party while steering clear of the crowds. Plus: The city's most stylish new hotels.. IT IS IMPOSSIBLE for Lauren Haydel to escape Mardi Gras.

title: Regulation and the Housing Affordability Crisis
summary: Government regulations account for nearly 25% of the price of building a single-family home.. Ben Lieberman's op-ed "A Regulatory Burden for Every Room in Your House" (Jan. 20) drives home how overzealous regulators are exacerbating the housing affordability crisis and severely limiting consumer choice. Home owners should be able to choose between electric and gas heating and the types of appliances and lighting that best meet their needs. Further, they should not have to pay a premium because faceless bureaucrats in Washington with contempt for freedom of choice wield the power to decide what's best for others.

title: New York Townhouse Asks $11.995 Million
summary: The Park Slope brownstone was renovated at a cost of roughly $6 million. A Brooklyn townhouse once divided into eight apartments is now a newly renovated single-family home, listing for $11.995 million.

title: Patients Go Without Covid-19 Treatments Amid Drug Shortage
summary: Different rules in different states create discrepancies in access to pills and treatments. Doctors and patients are trying to figure out how to obtain Covid-19 treatments under a patchwork system set up by states that are directing the distribution of limited supplies.

title: Covid and the 'Hygiene Hypothesis'
summary: Measures like masking and social distancing may be doing long-term damage to our immune systems.. Maintaining good health is often a balancing act. Too much food and we develop obesity, diabetes and heart disease. Too little food and we see stunting and wasting. This kind of equilibrium applies to our interactions with bacteria, viruses, parasites and other microbes. Too much exposure to some microbes leads to disease, and so does too little.

title: A Bipartisan Pivot in Biden's Second Year
summary: Congressional Democrats should give up delusions of political revolution.. What a difference a year makes.

title: December's Job Market Showed Resilience in the Face of Omicron
summary: Tuesday's report on labor turnover contains a couple more weeks' data than the December jobs report-and they are key weeks. What happened with the job market in December is in many respects old news. It just isn't as old as it used to be.

title: In China, Footage of a Chained-Up Rural Mother Draws Outcry
summary: Footage of a woman kept in a shed has triggered online calls for better protections for women and the mentally ill in rural China. Video footage of a woman chained up in a shed in a village in eastern China has hit a nerve just as the country heads into Lunar New Year celebrations and triggered online calls for better protections for women and the mentally ill in rural parts of the country.

title: Startup Investors Cut Valuations Amid Tech Stock Rout, Dismal IPOs
summary: Venture firms foresee tougher funding environment ahead, with more muted debuts after pandemic glut. The recent stock rout is rattling the multitrillion-dollar market for startups after a long run of record investments, nosebleed valuations and rapid-fire deal-making.

title: Tom Brady Is Going to Be Forever
summary: An NFL icon finally calls it quits, but he won't be a stranger. Tom Brady stops, it turns out!

title: Martin Sorrell's Comeback Plan: Take Down WPP and Other Giants
summary: The fallen ad chief is taking potshots at the giant he built over three decades, before quitting under pressure.. LONDON-Martin Sorrell built WPP PLC into the world's largest advertising agency over three decades through a combination of impatience, drive and the occasional angry outburst.

title: 'Glee' Star Matthew Morrison Lists L.A. Home for $4.295 Million
summary: Resume Subscription. Matthew Morrison, best known for his role in the Emmy-winning TV-show "Glee," is listing his Los Angeles home for $4.295 million.

title: Russia Confronts Ukraine With Upgraded Military Rebuilt After Soviet Collapse
summary: Resume Subscription. REUTOV, Russia-When the Soviet Union collapsed in the early 1990s, an elite military supplier once called Design Bureau No. 52, known for making intercontinental ballistic missiles, fell on hard times. Military spending had dropped so sharply that the company was forced to make civilian products such as railway timetable boards.

title: VR to the ER: Metaverse Early Adopters Prove Accident-Prone
summary: Tally includes broken vases, dislocated shoulders, injured girlfriends; 'Why don't you go to the gym like a normal person?'. A few hours after Toby Robicelli first strapped on the $300 virtual-reality headset he got for Christmas, the Baltimore teenager, who was playing a shooter game called "Superhot VR," lost his balance and fractured his kneecap.

title: Before 'Veep,' Matt Walsh Had a Brush With Harry S. Truman
summary: The 'Unplugging' actor was a class clown who was drawn to improv after traveling on trains in Austria.

title: Vol. 35, No. 1: Paul Martin Sr.
summary: Most Popular News. Paul Martin had a gentlemanly style, and plenty of substance. In 1987, he started The Wall Street Journal's Style & Substance editing bulletin that you're reading now, and even after he retired, he kept contributing to it behind the scenes.

title: Microsoft-Activision Deal to Be Reviewed by FTC
summary: Proposed $75 billion acquisition of videogame company will test merger enforcement under new Chairwoman Lina Khan. WASHINGTON- Microsoft Corp.'s proposed acquisition of Activision Blizzard Inc. will be reviewed in the U.S. by the Federal Trade Commission, a person familiar with the matter said, placing the fate of the roughly $75 billion deal in the hands of an agency whose leader has questioned acquisitions by powerful technology companies.

title: London Townhouse at Mega-Project to List for $78 Million
summary: Resume Subscription. One of the priciest residences in a London real-estate project backed by Qatar's sovereign-wealth fund is coming on the market for about $78 million, according to a representative for the developer.

title: U.S., Allies Wonder if They Can Count on Germany in Russia-Ukraine Crisis
summary: Longstanding ties and dependence on Russian gas leave Berlin isolated in NATO push to contain Moscow. BERLIN-Officials from Washington to London and Warsaw are asking whether Germany's heavy dependence on Russian gas, its post-World War II tendency to keep a low profile in international conflicts and its longstanding political and business links with Moscow are now making it an unreliable ally in the crisis in Ukraine.

title: Tom Brady Retires From NFL After 22 Seasons and Seven Super Bowl Wins
summary: The announcement came three days after reports of his retirement surfaced and fueled rampant speculation. Tom Brady has finally said he is done.

title: Thousands of Afghans Face Narrow Path to Gain Entry to U.S.
summary: Application denials on humanitarian grounds are sparking confusion and finger-pointing among administration officials, lawmakers and immigration advocates. A rarely used U.S. immigration program has come under immense strain as tens of thousands of Afghan refugees turn to it as their only hope to seek safe passage to the U.S.

title: Value Investing Is Back. But for How Long?
summary: A bounce in bond yields is good news for dividend payers. Value investing-buying stocks that are cheap on measures such as earnings or book value-is having a renaissance. Up to last Thursday, large value stocks beat more expensive "growth" stocks by the most of any 50-day period since the technology bubble burst in 2000-01, with the exception of the post-vaccine rebound early last year.

title: AMC, Alphabet, AT&T, Tesla, Moderna: What to Watch in the Stock Market Today
summary: Exxon Mobil said it is launching a $10 billion buyback program; Sony's videogame unit said it was buying Bungie. U.S. stocks and Treasury yields wavered, as investors awaited manufacturing data and earnings from big-name companies. Here's what we're following:

title: Still Feeling Pandemic Miserable? There Are Ways to Dig Out
summary: That exhaustion you are feeling is resilience fatigue. Here's how to handle it.. Many of us are hitting a new stage of pandemic slog in February.

title: Trump Reports $122 Million Political War Chest as He Weighs 2024 Bid
summary: Former president doled out donations to dozens of Republican candidates in the second half of last year. WASHINGTON-Former President Donald Trump has more than $122 million in cash spread across his post-presidency political operation and has made donations to dozens of Republican candidates for their midterm campaigns as he weighs another White House run, new Federal Election Commission filings show.

title: Mall Customers Shop for New Hips or Knees as Surgery Centers Fill Store Vacancies
summary: Hospitals and other healthcare providers are expanding into the empty spaces left behind as malls lose anchor retail tenants. The Marketplace Mall in Rochester, N.Y., has a food court, arcade games and plenty of fashion boutiques. Soon, it will perform hip replacements and rotator cuff surgeries, too.

title: Yves Klein For Your Home and a New Manhattan Gallery: The Best Designed Items of February
summary: A special Omega watch, new 'old-world' pillows, and everything else we can't stop obsessing over this month.. Arguably better than living with a painting you love would be living in it-and starting this month, admirers of the French artist Yves Klein can do just that. Working with the Yves Klein Archives, Pierre Frey has made wall coverings from two works Klein painted in 1960 with "living brushes," nude models drenched in ultramarine paint and set loose on a wall-size canvas. Up next will be three Klein carpets. One color option for all, of course: International Klein Blue. Yves Klein wallpaper, $2,780 for full panel set, PierreFrey.com. -Sarah Medford

title: Hailey Bieber's Next Move
summary: Resume Subscription. Even though she's sitting in a nondescript room where the lights appear to be off, Hailey Bieber somehow glows. The 25-year-old model, who's at home in Beverly Hills, has said that a goal of her beauty routine is to achieve "glazed donut" skin and, well, mission accomplished-even via video. She's dressed in loungewear-a marled sweater with a black long-sleeved shirt underneath-paired with minimalist jewelry and makeup. But her face is dewy, cheekbones flush with a swipe of something shimmery.

title: UBS Boosts Buybacks, Growth Targets
summary: Swiss bank says it will tap more customers globally for digital wealth advice. UBS Group AG said it would scale up its business in providing digital advice to keep up with competitors and changing wealth patterns.

title: UBS Is Well Prepared for Its American Adventure
summary: U.S. market has tripped up many European banks, but the Swiss wealth manager has a strong set of tools to break with the trend. UBS wants to push deeper into the U.S. European banks have a checkered history of trying to crack the American market, but the Swiss wealth manager is better set up for the challenge than most.

title: Alexis Ohanian's Venture-Capital Firm Raises $500 Million, Doubles Down on Crypto Startups
summary: Co-founder of Reddit says the majority of deals out of his VC firm 776 will be in crypto startups by year-end. Alexis Ohanian's venture firm 776 Management LLC has raised $500 million across two new funds with a plan to invest primarily in crypto startups.

title: Ukraine's Economy Braces for Impact as War With Russia Looms
summary: Businesses pause investments and Ukrainian currency comes under pressure as Russia masses troops on border. KYIV, Ukraine-Dobrobut, one of Ukraine's biggest private healthcare providers, is getting ready for a Russian invasion.

title: Marina Business Gets Lift From Pandemic Boat Sales
summary: Real-estate investor Centerbridge is combining the second- and third-largest marina owners to create a $2.5 billion company. The second-largest owner of U.S. marinas is acquiring the third-largest owner, creating a new powerhouse in this niche real-estate business as boat sales surge during the pandemic.

title: Do You Need a Covid-19 Vaccine Booster to Travel?
summary: More tourist destinations are granting easier entry for those who have received the extra vaccine shot. Two Covid-19 shots aren't enough for some travelers anymore. Destinations are now increasingly requiring boosters for easy entry.

title: Even for Olympic Gold-Winning Team USA, the Women's Hockey Pipeline Is Fractured
summary: But greater scrutiny of U.S. girls and women's hockey is spurring change at the college level, and the pro game is getting $25 million in cash.. Four years ago, the U.S. women's hockey team won its first Olympic gold medal since 1998 in the most dramatic fashion possible, beating archrival Canada in an overtime shootout. With the game concluding in the wee hours of the morning stateside, Hilary Knight, Kendall Coyne-Schofield and company were literally overnight sensations.

title: Myanmar's Junta Leader Said Eat More Meat, but People Are Struggling to Live
summary: Resume Subscription. SINGAPORE-Late last year, Myanmar's junta leader urged citizens of the country once known as Asia's rice bowl to eat less of their most ubiquitous crop. Food was abundant, Gen. Min Aung Hlaing said. Eat more meat, fish and vegetables.

title: Tractor Supply Focuses on Cost Cutting as Inflation Pressure Mounts
summary: Even as sales are booming, the outdoor retailer has beefed up its financial planning and procurement teams over the past year to help find cost savings. Outdoor retailer Tractor Supply Co. is hiring additional staff in its finance division to identify cost savings as the company, like many others, faces inflationary pressure on multiple fronts.

title: Noom Could Get Slim, Fast
summary: Recent controversy around digital apps and Noom in particular show investors' perception of the weight management company could be bloated. Fighting the Covid-15? This pandemic darling says it has helped its customers shed those extra pounds-and then some-in just a few months, on average. But the change might come with some unwanted baggage.

title: Covid-19's Economic Fallout Batters Latin America
summary: From Mexico to Brazil, growth is slow, inflation is rising, and people are leaving. Latin America, already pummeled by the pandemic, now faces a sharp increase in poverty and an exodus of its citizens to elsewhere in the world.

title: U.S. Companies Face More Restrictions After Privacy Ruling Against Google
summary: A decision against Google Analytics in Austria set the stage for European regulators to stop data flows to many American companies. American technology providers are under intense pressure in Europe after a regulator there found Google Analytics' services illegal. The decision is expected to spur a domino effect that could result in similar restrictions for other U.S. tech providers.

title: Economist Lisa Cook in Her Own Words
summary: The Biden Fed nominee has called for policies that promote broad economic opportunity, particularly for women and racial minorities. President Biden has nominated Lisa Cook, a professor of economics and international relations at Michigan State University, to join the Federal Reserve Board of Governors. She previously worked as a senior economist at the White House Council of Economic Advisers during the Obama administration and spent a year as a Treasury Department senior adviser during the Clinton and George W. Bush administrations.

title: Consumer Pessimism Grows as Inflation Accelerates
summary: U.S. consumer spending is now being tested by Omicron's persistence, waning fiscal stimulus, inflation and stock-market volatility. Consumer perception of current economic conditions in December was almost even with April 2020 levels, when sentiment bottomed out following the first major restrictions to control the coronavirus pandemic.

title: FDA Official Says New Rule Could Boost Blockchain-Based Food Tracking
summary: The proposed rule could spur adoption of a farm-to-fork food traceability program used by companies including Walmart and Nestlé. A Food and Drug Administration official said the regulator is writing new rules that could facilitate the adoption of blockchain technology in the food industry.

title: Peacock Looks to Winter Olympics for Second Chance
summary: Comcast's nascent streaming service will provide full access to live coverage after drawing criticism during Tokyo Games. Audie Norman signed up for Comcast Corp.'s Peacock last summer after hearing that the streaming service made it possible to watch the Tokyo Olympics without a pay-TV subscription, which he hasn't had in at least a decade.

title: Shintaro Ishihara, Japanese Conservative and China Antagonist, Dies at 89
summary: The firebrand politician co-authored 'The Japan That Can Say No' and played a pivotal role in escalating territorial tensions with China. TOKYO-Shintaro Ishihara, the Japanese conservative firebrand who once antagonized the U.S. with his book "The Japan That Can Say No" and later played a pivotal role in escalating territorial tensions with China, died Tuesday at age 89, his family said.

title: Somaliland Offers U.S. Military Access to Port, Airfield as It Pushes for Nationhood
summary: Region is seeking to break from Somalia and sees Washington as potentially powerful ally. NAIROBI-Somaliland, a peaceful corner of violent Somalia, is offering the U.S. military use of a seaport and airfield overlooking strategic maritime routes in exchange for steps toward recognizing the region as a sovereign country.

title: Rio Tinto Says Racism, Sexual Harassment Widespread at Miner
summary: Report commissioned by company finds nearly half of workers have experienced bullying, 28% of women have been sexually harassed. SYDNEY-When one Rio Tinto PLC worker reported she had been sexually harassed by a colleague, a manager told her it had probably been meant as a joke. Another employee said they felt so unsafe in the presence of a male manager that they had contemplated suicide.

title: Australia Central Bank Ends Key Pandemic Program
summary: The halt to government-bond purchases doesn't imply it will soon raise interest rates, Reserve Bank of Australia governor says. SYDNEY-The Reserve Bank of Australia will end a bond-buying program that has anchored its response to the Covid-19 pandemic, given accelerated inflation and a tight job market.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: What Is a Stock Split and How Does It Affect Your Portfolio?
summary: The ins and outs of stock splits, which don't happen as often as they did in the past. Google parent Alphabet Inc. announced Tuesday that it would split its stock 20-for-1. Stock splits change the stock price and not much else, but they can be confusing anyway.

title: One Million Deaths: The Hole the Pandemic Made in U.S. Society
summary: Covid-19 has been directly responsible for most of the fatalities, but the disease is also unraveling families and communities in subtler ways. Two years into the Covid-19 pandemic, America's death toll is closing in on one million.

title: What Are Hypersonic Missiles and Who's Developing Them?
summary: Missile tests by U.S. rivals raise pressure for defenses and America's own hypersonic missiles. Recent hypersonic missile tests by North Korea and China have highlighted the challenge of coming up with effective defenses against the advanced weapons, as well as the difficulties the U.S. has had in developing its own hypersonic-missile program. Here's a guide to hypersonic missiles.

title: U.S. Bobsled Medalist Tests Covid-Positive at Beijing Olympics
summary: Elana Meyers Taylor, a three-time medalist, was staying with her husband, 1-year-old son and a caretaker at a hotel. Elana Meyers Taylor, a three-time Olympic medal-winning bobsledder for Team USA and the mother of a 1-year-old, tested positive for Covid-19 inside the "closed loop" for the Beijing Olympics, which open Friday.

title: California Single-Payer Healthcare Plan Shelved at Last Minute
summary: Author of a bill to establish the first state-run universal health plan concluded there weren't enough votes for passage. A bill that would have established the first single-payer healthcare system in the U.S. was pulled from consideration hours before a planned vote in the California Assembly Monday after its author concluded there wasn't enough support for it to pass.

title: Videogame Maker Electronic Arts Hires Microsoft Executive as CFO
summary: Chris Suh, CFO of Microsoft's cloud and artificial intelligence unit, is set to begin his new role March 1. Videogame maker Electronic Arts Inc. hired Microsoft Corp. executive Chris Suh as chief financial officer, succeeding Blake Jorgensen, who announced his departure in September.

title: Tom Brady Says He Will Decide 'When the Time Is Right' After Retirement Reports
summary: Two days after reports surfaced about the NFL legend's imminent retirement, the quarterback made his first public comments and indicated he is still making up his mind. NFL great Tom Brady indicated he hasn't yet made a decision about whether to retire in his first public comments since published reports said he planned to end his playing career after 22 seasons and seven championships.

title: Sony's Bungie Jump Won't Scare Microsoft
summary: PlayStation maker picks up another strong developer, but deal doesn't bring a lot of owned IP. Competing with Big Tech's wallet is hard, even for slightly smaller techs.
